Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the moon illusion?
Options: A. The fact that the same side of the moon is always facing earth, B. The appearance of a “man in the moon”, C. The apparent change in size of the moon as it rises and sets, D. The disappearance of the moon during a lunar eclipse
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the "moon illusion"? Options: A. The phenomenon where the full moon appears smaller when near the horizon than when high overhead., B. The phenomenon where the full moon appears bigger when near the horizon than when high overhead., C. The phenomenon where the full moon appears the same size regardless of its position in the sky., D. The phenomenon where the full moon appears to change color when near the horizon. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following explanations for the moon illusion suggests that the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets? Options: A. Ebbinghaus Illusion, B. Ponzo Illusion, C. Convergence Micropsia, D. Atmospheric Refraction Correct Option: None
Question 3: According to the Ebbinghaus Illusion, why might the moon appear bigger near the horizon? Options: A. Because it is surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky., B. Because it is next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance., C. Because our brain compensates automatically for the perspective of objects near the horizon., D. Because the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the Ponzo Illusion? Options: A. An optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to the relative size of surrounding objects., B. An optical illusion where objects near the horizon appear larger due to our brain's automatic compensation for perspective., C. An optical illusion where objects appear smaller when viewed from a distance., D. An optical illusion where objects appear larger when viewed from a close distance. Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why does the Convergence Micropsia explanation suggest that the moon appears smaller when overhead? Options: A. Because our brain thinks the moon is farther away than it really is., B. Because our brain thinks the moon is closer than it really is., C. Because the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon., D. Because our eyes focus on a point just a few meters away when looking up at the night sky. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What happens to the moon illusion when viewed from a high altitude, such as by pilots flying above the clouds? Options: A. It disappears entirely., B. It becomes more pronounced., C. It remains the same., D. It is unaffected. Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to studies, what happens to the moon illusion when viewed inside a planetarium? Options: A. It becomes more pronounced., B. It remains the same., C. It disappears entirely., D. It is unaffected. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the effect of bending over and looking at the moon between one's legs on the moon illusion? Options: A. It becomes more pronounced., B. It remains the same., C. It disappears entirely., D. It is unaffected. Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which of the following scientists is NOT mentioned as having attempted to explain the moon illusion? Options: A. Aristotle, B. Ptolemy, C. Da Vinci, D. Galileo Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of the debate over the moon illusion? Options: A. It has been fully explained and resolved., B. It is still ongoing and unresolved., C. It has been partially explained, but more research is needed., D. It is no longer a topic of interest in the scientific community. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the options in Question 1 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the question intent and content are similar. Question 1 asks about the definition of the "moon illusion," which aligns with the ground truth MCQ. The correct answer can be inferred as Option B, "The phenomenon where the full moon appears bigger when near the horizon than when high overhead," which is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "The apparent change in size of the moon as it rises and sets."

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What effect could the atmosphere have in contributing to the moon illusion?
Options: A. The atmosphere would make the moon appear smaller at sunrise or sunset., B. The atmosphere would make the moon disappear at sunrise or sunset., C. The atmosphere changes the apparent color of the moon., D. The atmosphere makes it look like the same side of the moon always faces us.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which sentence best describes the Ebbinghaus illusion?
Options: A. Two identical circles appear different because of the relative size of objects around them., B. Our brains overestimate the size of objects located closer to the horizon., C. Pilots in airplanes have nothing to compare the moon’s size to, so it looks smaller., D. The focus of our eyes impacts how large we perceive an object to be.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question directly asks about the Ponzo Illusion, which is the same topic as the ground truth MCQ. The correct answer in Question 4 (Option B) also matches the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ (Option B), which describes the Ponzo Illusion as an optical illusion where objects near the horizon appear larger due to our brain's automatic compensation for perspective.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed how the full moon looks bigger when it's near the horizon than when it's high over head? If so, you're not alone. People have wondered about this strange effect since ancient times, and surprisingly, we still don't have a great explanation, but that's not for lack of trying. Some of the greatest minds in history - Aristotle, Ptolemy, Da Vinci, Decartes - have all wrestled with this problem and failed to generate an adequate explanation. One of the first ideas suggested was that the image of the moon in the sky really is bigger near the horizon. Perhaps the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets. But this explanation doesn't cut it. If anything, the refraction of the atmosphere would make the moon look slightly smaller. Plus, if you actually measure the size of the visible moon at different positions, it doesn't change at all. But then, why does it still seem bigger when it's rising? This must be some kind of optical illusion. The question is, which one? One explanation is the Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by. Here the two center circles are actually the same size. Maybe the moon looks bigger near the horizon because it's next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance. But when the moon is higher up, it's surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky and looks tiny by comparison. Another possibility is the famous Ponzo Illusion. If you've ever tried to draw in perspective, you know that the closer something is to the horizon, the smaller you should draw it. Our brain compensates automatically for this by perceiving objects near the horizon as larger than they actually appear. The two yellow lines in this drawing are the same size, but the upper one seems bigger because we interpret it as receding farther into the horizon. So, between Ponzo and Ebbinghaus, it seems like we've solved the mystery of the moon illusion, but, unfortunately, there are a few details that complicate things. For one thing, if this was just the Ebbinghaus effect, then we would expect the moon illusion to disappear for pilots flying high above the clouds since there wouldn't be any other smaller objects near the horizon. But in fact, pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion. On the other hand, if it's just our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon, then we'd expect the moon illusion to be visible inside a planetarium, where the whole sky, including the horizon, is displayed on a spherical dome overhead. Studies have shown, though, that this is not the case. To make matters worse, it seems the moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs. Now, this is just getting ridiculous! One of the most promising explanations today is known as Convergence Micropsia. Our brains judge the distance to objects and their apparent size by the focus of our eyes. When looking at the horizon, your eyes focus far off into the distance so your brain knows you're looking far away. The moon appears a certain size. Your brain thinks it's far away, which it is, so you naturally conclude the moon must be big. But when looking up at the night sky, there's nothing for your eyes to focus on, so they default to their rest focus, which is a point just a few meters away. Now your brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is, so you naturally conclude the moon's not as big as you thought it was. Rather than explain why the moon looks so big near the horizon, Convergence Microspia explains why the moon looks so small when overhead. Still not satisfied? Well, frankly, neither are many scientists, so the debate over the moon illusion still rages on and may continue as long as we still see it in the night sky.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name given to the most promising explanation of the moon illusion?
Options: A. Refraction, B. Ebbinghaus illusion, C. Ponzo illusion, D. Convergence micropsia
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the "moon illusion"? Options: A. The phenomenon where the full moon appears smaller when near the horizon than when high overhead., B. The phenomenon where the full moon appears bigger when near the horizon than when high overhead., C. The phenomenon where the full moon appears the same size regardless of its position in the sky., D. The phenomenon where the full moon appears to change color when near the horizon. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following explanations for the moon illusion suggests that the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets? Options: A. Ebbinghaus Illusion, B. Ponzo Illusion, C. Convergence Micropsia, D. Atmospheric Refraction Correct Option: None
Question 3: According to the Ebbinghaus Illusion, why might the moon appear bigger near the horizon? Options: A. Because it is surrounded by the vast darkness of the night sky., B. Because it is next to tiny trees, houses, and towers in the distance., C. Because our brain compensates automatically for the perspective of objects near the horizon., D. Because the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the Ponzo Illusion? Options: A. An optical illusion where two identical objects appear different due to the relative size of surrounding objects., B. An optical illusion where objects near the horizon appear larger due to our brain's automatic compensation for perspective., C. An optical illusion where objects appear smaller when viewed from a distance., D. An optical illusion where objects appear larger when viewed from a close distance. Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why does the Convergence Micropsia explanation suggest that the moon appears smaller when overhead? Options: A. Because our brain thinks the moon is farther away than it really is., B. Because our brain thinks the moon is closer than it really is., C. Because the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon., D. Because our eyes focus on a point just a few meters away when looking up at the night sky. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What happens to the moon illusion when viewed from a high altitude, such as by pilots flying above the clouds? Options: A. It disappears entirely., B. It becomes more pronounced., C. It remains the same., D. It is unaffected. Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to studies, what happens to the moon illusion when viewed inside a planetarium? Options: A. It becomes more pronounced., B. It remains the same., C. It disappears entirely., D. It is unaffected. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the effect of bending over and looking at the moon between one's legs on the moon illusion? Options: A. It becomes more pronounced., B. It remains the same., C. It disappears entirely., D. It is unaffected. Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which of the following scientists is NOT mentioned as having attempted to explain the moon illusion? Options: A. Aristotle, B. Ptolemy, C. Da Vinci, D. Galileo Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of the debate over the moon illusion? Options: A. It has been fully explained and resolved., B. It is still ongoing and unresolved., C. It has been partially explained, but more research is needed., D. It is no longer a topic of interest in the scientific community. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Although this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest match in terms of content and intent. The ground truth MCQ asks for the name of the most promising explanation of the moon illusion, which is Convergence Micropsia. Question 5 is related to Convergence Micropsia and provides some information about this explanation.

However, I must note that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable generated MCQ would be one that asks for the name of the most promising explanation of the moon illusion, with options that include Convergence Micropsia.

If I had to choose an index, I would choose **5**, but with the caveat that the generated MCQs do not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Options: A. Refraction, B. Ebbinghaus illusion, C. Ponzo illusion, D. Convergence micropsia

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you experienced déjà vu? It's that shadowy feeling you get
when a situation seems familiar. A scene in a restaurant plays out
exactly as you remember. The world moves like a ballet
you've choreographed, but the sequence can't be based
on a past experience because you've never eaten here before. This is the first time you've had clams, so what's going on? Unfortunately, there isn't
one single explanation for déjà vu. The experience is brief
and occurs without notice, making it nearly impossible
for scientists to record and study it. Scientists can't simply sit around
and wait for it to happen to them -- this could take years. It has no physical manifestations and in studies, it's described by the subject
as a sensation or feeling. Because of this lack of hard evidence, there's been a surplus
of speculation over the years. Since Emile Boirac introduced déjà vu as a French term meaning "already seen," more than 40 theories attempt
to explain this phenomenon. Still, recent advancements in neuroimaging
and cognitive psychology narrow down the field of prospects. Let's walk through three of today's
more prevalent theories, using the same
restaurant setting for each. First up is dual processing. We'll need an action. Let's go with a waiter
dropping a tray of dishes. As the scene unfolds, your brain's hemispheres process
a flurry of information: the waiter's flailing arms, his cry for help, the smell of pasta. Within milliseconds, this information
zips through pathways and is processed into a single moment. Most of the time,
everything is recorded in-sync. However, this theory asserts that déjà vu occurs
when there's a slight delay in information from one of these pathways. The difference in arrival times causes the brain to interpret
the late information as a separate event. When it plays
over the already-recorded moment, it feels as if it's happened before because, in a sense, it has. Our next theory deals
with a confusion of the past rather than a mistake in the present. This is the hologram theory, and we'll use that tablecloth
to examine it. As you scan its squares, a distant memory swims up
from deep within your brain. According to the theory, this is because memories are stored in the form of holograms, and in holograms, you only need one fragment
to see the whole picture. Your brain has identified the tablecloth
with one from the past, maybe from your grandmother's house. However, instead of remembering
that you've seen it at your grandmother's, your brain has summoned up the old memory without identifying it. This leaves you stuck with familiarity,
but no recollection. Although you've never been
in this restaurant, you've seen that tablecloth
but are just failing to identify it. Now, look at this fork. Are you paying attention? Our last theory is divided attention, and it states that déjà vu occurs when our brain subliminally
takes in an environment while we're distracted
by one particular object. When our attention returns, we feel as if we've been here before. For example, just now
you focused on the fork and didn't observe the tablecloth
or the falling waiter. Although your brain has been
recording everything in your peripheral vision, it's been doing so
below conscious awareness. When you finally pull yourself
away from the fork, you think you've been here before
because you have, you just weren't paying attention. While all three of these theories
share the common features of déjà vu, none of them propose to be
the conclusive source of the phenomenon. Still, while we wait
for researchers and inventers to come up with new ways
to capture this fleeting moment, we can study the moment ourselves. After all, most studies of déjà vu
are based on first-hand accounts, so why can't one be yours? The next time you get déjà vu,
take a moment to think about it. Have you been distracted? Is there a familiar object somewhere? Is your brain just acting slow? Or is it something else?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the physical manifestations of déjà vu?
Options: A. Dizziness, B. Ringing in the ears, C. Sneezing, D. None
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is déjà vu? Options: A. A feeling of being in a completely new environment., B. A feeling of being in a familiar environment, even if you've never been there before., C. A feeling of being in a past life., D. A feeling of being in a dream state. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why is it difficult for scientists to study déjà vu? Options: A. Because it is a rare occurrence., B. Because it is a brief experience and occurs without notice., C. Because it has no physical manifestations., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What does the term "déjà vu" mean in French? Options: A. "Already seen", B. "Familiar feeling", C. "Past experience", D. "Memory lapse" Correct Option: None
Question 4: How many theories have been proposed to explain déjà vu? Options: A. Over 10, B. Over 20, C. Over 40, D. Over 50 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the dual processing theory of déjà vu? Options: A. It occurs when there's a slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., B. It occurs when the brain confuses the past with the present., C. It occurs when the brain is distracted by a particular object., D. It occurs when the brain is in a state of high alert. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the hologram theory of déjà vu? Options: A. It occurs when the brain stores memories in the form of holograms., B. It occurs when the brain confuses the past with the present., C. It occurs when the brain is distracted by a particular object., D. It occurs when the brain is in a state of high alert. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the divided attention theory of déjà vu? Options: A. It occurs when the brain is distracted by a particular object., B. It occurs when the brain confuses the past with the present., C. It occurs when there's a slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., D. It occurs when the brain is in a state of high alert. Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why is it important to study déjà vu? Options: A. Because it can help us understand the brain's processing mechanisms., B. Because it can help us understand the nature of memory., C. Because it can help us understand the nature of perception., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How can individuals contribute to the study of déjà vu? Options: A. By reporting their experiences to researchers., B. By keeping a journal of their experiences., C. By participating in experiments., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What should you do the next time you experience déjà vu? Options: A. Try to ignore it., B. Take a moment to think about it and try to understand what might be causing it., C. Try to recreate the experience., D. Tell someone about it. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: Why is it difficult for scientists to study déjà vu? Options: A. Because it is a rare occurrence., B. Because it is a brief experience and occurs without notice., C. Because it has no physical manifestations., D. All of the above.

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it mentions the lack of physical manifestations as one of the reasons why it is difficult to study déjà vu. The ground truth MCQ directly asks about the physical manifestations of déjà vu and states that there are none.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you experienced déjà vu? It's that shadowy feeling you get
when a situation seems familiar. A scene in a restaurant plays out
exactly as you remember. The world moves like a ballet
you've choreographed, but the sequence can't be based
on a past experience because you've never eaten here before. This is the first time you've had clams, so what's going on? Unfortunately, there isn't
one single explanation for déjà vu. The experience is brief
and occurs without notice, making it nearly impossible
for scientists to record and study it. Scientists can't simply sit around
and wait for it to happen to them -- this could take years. It has no physical manifestations and in studies, it's described by the subject
as a sensation or feeling. Because of this lack of hard evidence, there's been a surplus
of speculation over the years. Since Emile Boirac introduced déjà vu as a French term meaning "already seen," more than 40 theories attempt
to explain this phenomenon. Still, recent advancements in neuroimaging
and cognitive psychology narrow down the field of prospects. Let's walk through three of today's
more prevalent theories, using the same
restaurant setting for each. First up is dual processing. We'll need an action. Let's go with a waiter
dropping a tray of dishes. As the scene unfolds, your brain's hemispheres process
a flurry of information: the waiter's flailing arms, his cry for help, the smell of pasta. Within milliseconds, this information
zips through pathways and is processed into a single moment. Most of the time,
everything is recorded in-sync. However, this theory asserts that déjà vu occurs
when there's a slight delay in information from one of these pathways. The difference in arrival times causes the brain to interpret
the late information as a separate event. When it plays
over the already-recorded moment, it feels as if it's happened before because, in a sense, it has. Our next theory deals
with a confusion of the past rather than a mistake in the present. This is the hologram theory, and we'll use that tablecloth
to examine it. As you scan its squares, a distant memory swims up
from deep within your brain. According to the theory, this is because memories are stored in the form of holograms, and in holograms, you only need one fragment
to see the whole picture. Your brain has identified the tablecloth
with one from the past, maybe from your grandmother's house. However, instead of remembering
that you've seen it at your grandmother's, your brain has summoned up the old memory without identifying it. This leaves you stuck with familiarity,
but no recollection. Although you've never been
in this restaurant, you've seen that tablecloth
but are just failing to identify it. Now, look at this fork. Are you paying attention? Our last theory is divided attention, and it states that déjà vu occurs when our brain subliminally
takes in an environment while we're distracted
by one particular object. When our attention returns, we feel as if we've been here before. For example, just now
you focused on the fork and didn't observe the tablecloth
or the falling waiter. Although your brain has been
recording everything in your peripheral vision, it's been doing so
below conscious awareness. When you finally pull yourself
away from the fork, you think you've been here before
because you have, you just weren't paying attention. While all three of these theories
share the common features of déjà vu, none of them propose to be
the conclusive source of the phenomenon. Still, while we wait
for researchers and inventers to come up with new ways
to capture this fleeting moment, we can study the moment ourselves. After all, most studies of déjà vu
are based on first-hand accounts, so why can't one be yours? The next time you get déjà vu,
take a moment to think about it. Have you been distracted? Is there a familiar object somewhere? Is your brain just acting slow? Or is it something else?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which theory asserts that déjà vu occurs when there is a delay in information to your brian?
Options: A. Double imaging, B. Delayed Response, C. Hologram Theory, D. Dual Processing
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is déjà vu? Options: A. A feeling of being in a completely new environment., B. A feeling of being in a familiar environment, even if you've never been there before., C. A feeling of being in a past life., D. A feeling of being in a dream state. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why is it difficult for scientists to study déjà vu? Options: A. Because it is a rare occurrence., B. Because it is a brief experience and occurs without notice., C. Because it has no physical manifestations., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What does the term "déjà vu" mean in French? Options: A. "Already seen", B. "Familiar feeling", C. "Past experience", D. "Memory lapse" Correct Option: None
Question 4: How many theories have been proposed to explain déjà vu? Options: A. Over 10, B. Over 20, C. Over 40, D. Over 50 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the dual processing theory of déjà vu? Options: A. It occurs when there's a slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., B. It occurs when the brain confuses the past with the present., C. It occurs when the brain is distracted by a particular object., D. It occurs when the brain is in a state of high alert. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the hologram theory of déjà vu? Options: A. It occurs when the brain stores memories in the form of holograms., B. It occurs when the brain confuses the past with the present., C. It occurs when the brain is distracted by a particular object., D. It occurs when the brain is in a state of high alert. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the divided attention theory of déjà vu? Options: A. It occurs when the brain is distracted by a particular object., B. It occurs when the brain confuses the past with the present., C. It occurs when there's a slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways., D. It occurs when the brain is in a state of high alert. Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why is it important to study déjà vu? Options: A. Because it can help us understand the brain's processing mechanisms., B. Because it can help us understand the nature of memory., C. Because it can help us understand the nature of perception., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How can individuals contribute to the study of déjà vu? Options: A. By reporting their experiences to researchers., B. By keeping a journal of their experiences., C. By participating in experiments., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What should you do the next time you experience déjà vu? Options: A. Try to ignore it., B. Take a moment to think about it and try to understand what might be causing it., C. Try to recreate the experience., D. Tell someone about it. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the theory that asserts that déjà vu occurs when there is a delay in information to the brain. The correct option in Question 5, "It occurs when there's a slight delay in information from one of the brain's pathways," matches the description of the dual processing theory in the transcript, which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. But Shakespearean works are not boring, confusing, long and painful plays written more than 400 years ago. They're adventures relating to the extremities of human nature: love, hate, jealousy, zealous ambition, fear, mistrust, deception, and murder. We owe much of our own language to his invention. He invented over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which still remain in the Oxford English Dictionary. Words like "countless" and "assassination" as well as phrases like "one fell swoop," "foul play," and even "to be in a pickle" all originated from William's brilliant brain. And there are many echoes of Shakespeare's romantic language too. If you read Romeo and Juliet, you'll come across sentences like, "She doth teach the torches to burn bright," and, "So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows." Both are quite clever metaphors, suggesting that Juliet is both exceptionally beautiful and far moreso than anyone else. "For thou art as glorious to this night, being o'er my head, as is a winged messenger of heaven," is a simile suggesting angelic qualities of the lady in question. This is not too different from today's comments like, "Hey, beautiful!" and, "You're the hottest girl in the room." Shakespeare also uses slightly more complex metaphors to describe the intentions of a mischievous man. For instance, "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss," essentially means, "I wish to kiss you." Such male intentions were not limited to simple pecks on the cheek either. An intentional ambiguity was often used as a cheeky means to proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship. Therefore, instead of viewing Shakespearean works as out-dated, boring, and unhelpful, start reading today and discover the best ways to get the one you love to love you back.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Shakespeare’s plays were written in the ________.
Options: A. 1500's and 1600's, B. 1100's and 1200's, C. 2000 BC, D. 1960's
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the common reaction of students when a teacher mentions the word "Shakespeare" in a 21st-century classroom? Options: A. Excitement and enthusiasm, B. Indifference and apathy, C. Groans, moans, and devastated looks, D. Cheers and applause Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are Shakespearean works primarily about? Options: A. Historical events and dates, B. Scientific discoveries and theories, C. Adventures relating to the extremities of human nature, D. Mythological creatures and legends Correct Option: None
Question 3: How many words did Shakespeare invent for use in his plays? Options: A. Over 1,000 words, B. Over 2,000 words, C. Over 5,000 words, D. Over 10,000 words Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following phrases originated from Shakespeare's plays? Options: A. "Break a leg", B. "To be in a pickle", C. "Bite the bullet", D. "Cost an arm and a leg" Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of Shakespeare's romantic language in his plays? Options: A. To confuse and intimidate the audience, B. To create a sense of fear and anxiety, C. To describe the beauty and qualities of a loved one, D. To promote violence and aggression Correct Option: None
Question 6: What literary device does Shakespeare use to describe Juliet's beauty in Romeo and Juliet? Options: A. Simile, B. Metaphor, C. Alliteration, D. Personification Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the meaning of the phrase "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss"? Options: A. I wish to kiss you, B. I wish to marry you, C. I wish to be friends with you, D. I wish to ignore you Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why did Shakespeare use intentional ambiguity in his plays? Options: A. To confuse the audience, B. To create a sense of mystery, C. To proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship, D. To promote violence and aggression Correct Option: None
Question 9: How should one view Shakespearean works? Options: A. As outdated, boring, and unhelpful, B. As exciting, relevant, and helpful, C. As confusing, complex, and unnecessary, D. As historical, cultural, and insignificant Correct Option: None
Question 10: What can one gain from reading Shakespearean works? Options: A. Knowledge of historical events and dates, B. Understanding of scientific discoveries and theories, C. Insight into human nature and relationships, D. Familiarity with mythological creatures and legends Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided set. However, based on the question content, options, and overall intent, I can suggest a related generated MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the time period when Shakespeare's plays were written. Although there isn't a direct match among the generated MCQs, Question 3 mentions a related fact about Shakespeare inventing over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which are still present in the Oxford English Dictionary. This implies that Shakespeare's works were written in the past, but it doesn't explicitly specify the time period.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would select Question 3. However, please note that it's not a direct match.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. A more similar MCQ would have options that include phrases mentioned in the ground truth MCQ, such as "foul play", "to be in a pickle", and "she doth teach the torches to burn bright". 

If I had to choose from the given options, I would say that Question 4 is the most similar, but a more accurate match would require a generated MCQ with more similar options.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. But Shakespearean works are not boring, confusing, long and painful plays written more than 400 years ago. They're adventures relating to the extremities of human nature: love, hate, jealousy, zealous ambition, fear, mistrust, deception, and murder. We owe much of our own language to his invention. He invented over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which still remain in the Oxford English Dictionary. Words like "countless" and "assassination" as well as phrases like "one fell swoop," "foul play," and even "to be in a pickle" all originated from William's brilliant brain. And there are many echoes of Shakespeare's romantic language too. If you read Romeo and Juliet, you'll come across sentences like, "She doth teach the torches to burn bright," and, "So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows." Both are quite clever metaphors, suggesting that Juliet is both exceptionally beautiful and far moreso than anyone else. "For thou art as glorious to this night, being o'er my head, as is a winged messenger of heaven," is a simile suggesting angelic qualities of the lady in question. This is not too different from today's comments like, "Hey, beautiful!" and, "You're the hottest girl in the room." Shakespeare also uses slightly more complex metaphors to describe the intentions of a mischievous man. For instance, "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss," essentially means, "I wish to kiss you." Such male intentions were not limited to simple pecks on the cheek either. An intentional ambiguity was often used as a cheeky means to proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship. Therefore, instead of viewing Shakespearean works as out-dated, boring, and unhelpful, start reading today and discover the best ways to get the one you love to love you back.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this my lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss" means: _______.
Options: A. I wish to kiss you, B. kissing is a sin, C. pilgrims kiss roughly, D. everyone wants to kiss you
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the common reaction of students when a teacher mentions the word "Shakespeare" in a 21st-century classroom? Options: A. Excitement and enthusiasm, B. Indifference and apathy, C. Groans, moans, and devastated looks, D. Cheers and applause Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are Shakespearean works primarily about? Options: A. Historical events and dates, B. Scientific discoveries and theories, C. Adventures relating to the extremities of human nature, D. Mythological creatures and legends Correct Option: None
Question 3: How many words did Shakespeare invent for use in his plays? Options: A. Over 1,000 words, B. Over 2,000 words, C. Over 5,000 words, D. Over 10,000 words Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following phrases originated from Shakespeare's plays? Options: A. "Break a leg", B. "To be in a pickle", C. "Bite the bullet", D. "Cost an arm and a leg" Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of Shakespeare's romantic language in his plays? Options: A. To confuse and intimidate the audience, B. To create a sense of fear and anxiety, C. To describe the beauty and qualities of a loved one, D. To promote violence and aggression Correct Option: None
Question 6: What literary device does Shakespeare use to describe Juliet's beauty in Romeo and Juliet? Options: A. Simile, B. Metaphor, C. Alliteration, D. Personification Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the meaning of the phrase "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss"? Options: A. I wish to kiss you, B. I wish to marry you, C. I wish to be friends with you, D. I wish to ignore you Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why did Shakespeare use intentional ambiguity in his plays? Options: A. To confuse the audience, B. To create a sense of mystery, C. To proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship, D. To promote violence and aggression Correct Option: None
Question 9: How should one view Shakespearean works? Options: A. As outdated, boring, and unhelpful, B. As exciting, relevant, and helpful, C. As confusing, complex, and unnecessary, D. As historical, cultural, and insignificant Correct Option: None
Question 10: What can one gain from reading Shakespearean works? Options: A. Knowledge of historical events and dates, B. Understanding of scientific discoveries and theories, C. Insight into human nature and relationships, D. Familiarity with mythological creatures and legends Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Using the word Shakespeare within any classroom in the 21st century has become almost as dangerous for teachers as putting balloons in a toaster. After uttering this simple word, the common teacher is met with a mass of groans, moans, devastated looks, and the occasional chair tossed in his or her direction. But Shakespearean works are not boring, confusing, long and painful plays written more than 400 years ago. They're adventures relating to the extremities of human nature: love, hate, jealousy, zealous ambition, fear, mistrust, deception, and murder. We owe much of our own language to his invention. He invented over 2,000 words for use in his plays, which still remain in the Oxford English Dictionary. Words like "countless" and "assassination" as well as phrases like "one fell swoop," "foul play," and even "to be in a pickle" all originated from William's brilliant brain. And there are many echoes of Shakespeare's romantic language too. If you read Romeo and Juliet, you'll come across sentences like, "She doth teach the torches to burn bright," and, "So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows." Both are quite clever metaphors, suggesting that Juliet is both exceptionally beautiful and far moreso than anyone else. "For thou art as glorious to this night, being o'er my head, as is a winged messenger of heaven," is a simile suggesting angelic qualities of the lady in question. This is not too different from today's comments like, "Hey, beautiful!" and, "You're the hottest girl in the room." Shakespeare also uses slightly more complex metaphors to describe the intentions of a mischievous man. For instance, "This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand to smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss," essentially means, "I wish to kiss you." Such male intentions were not limited to simple pecks on the cheek either. An intentional ambiguity was often used as a cheeky means to proposition marriage or a more intimate relationship. Therefore, instead of viewing Shakespearean works as out-dated, boring, and unhelpful, start reading today and discover the best ways to get the one you love to love you back.

Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As you can see, I was born without fingers on my right hand. And also my right leg was several inches shorter than my left one. They broke the bones in the leg, then they screwed metal spikes into the bone. It has not only spikes, but wires that go all the way through the leg to stabilize it. I have to walk on it. I have to stretch it out so that my muscles don't just get all atrophied. People always ask me, "Does it hurt?" Yes, it does, but I focus on what I can do, not on what I cannot do. I want to talk with you guys about overcoming obstacles. Everybody has obstacles, a disability, a hurdle. We face a choice: Let the obstacle overcome you or overcome the obstacle. Maybe some of you have heard of Jim Abbott. He was a Major League baseball player. He won a gold metal in the Olympics. He played for the Yankees, the Angels. But he threw a no-hitter, and he only had one arm. When he was a kid, he came home mad one time and told his dad, "The kids won't let me play baseball because I only have one hand." His dad replied, "No, the kids won't let you play baseball because you stink at baseball. You can't change the fact that you only have one hand, but you can change the fact that you stink." So, his dad began to practice with him, and he got good. He overcame obstacles. Teams would try to exploit his weak side. They would try to bunt to the side that he had a missing arm. But they never succeeded because he practiced and practiced fielding bunts to that side. There's no dishonor in having a disability, and I won't let anyone diss my ability, but I don't want anyone's pity either. I will not use the obstacles I face as an excuse for having a pity party. I will practice harder, play harder, and push myself harder to keep getting better. Last season I started on my varsity high school basketball team as a freshman, and I won Rookie of the Year. I was one of the top scorers on the team. One of the things that I find funny is that people judge me by appearance. They say, "Oh, look at this one-handed whitey with the limp. I don't want him on my team!" But what they don't know is that I don't just have a disability, I have an ability. One of my favorite moments from this last season was we played a team that we had never played before. And when the game started, you could tell that they were dissing my disability. I mean, they double-teamed our tallest player. They just were playing really soft on me, and they just, you could tell they thought, "What can this guy with one hand do?" So, they left me open for a three. I made that one. They left me open for another one. I made that one. Then, they started to get frustrated, so they actually fouled me. I made both free throws. And they called time out. And as we were in the huddle, I could hear the other coach yelling at his players about me. They went from not covering me at all to double-teaming me. It's all about overcoming obstacles. It's true, I have a disability, but so do you. I also have an ability, so do you. Everyone has obstacles to overcome. Some are visible like mine. Some are less visible. Maybe your obstacle is that you come from a poor neighborhood. Maybe people say you'll never amount to anything. Prove them wrong. Maybe your obstacle is that you have a learning disability, and people think that you're dumb. Prove them wrong. Maybe people judge you because of the color of your skin or your family background. Prove them wrong. I know a lot of people who take one look at me and judge me. They say, "Oh, that kid can't be any good at basketball. One leg, one hand." If someone things you can't overcome the obstacles, prove them wrong.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which activity helped Steven overcome his obstacles?
Options: A. Playing football, B. Singing, C. Playing basketball, D. Swimming
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: What is the speaker's physical condition? Options: A. He was born without fingers on his left hand and has a shorter right leg., B. He was born without fingers on his right hand and has a shorter right leg., C. He was born with a missing arm and has a shorter left leg., D. He was born with a missing leg and has a shorter right arm. Correct Option: None
Question 3: How did the speaker's father help him overcome his physical limitations? Options: A. By encouraging him to focus on his disability, B. By practicing with him to improve his skills, C. By telling him to give up on his dreams, D. By ignoring his disability and treating him like everyone else Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the speaker's attitude towards his disability? Options: A. He is ashamed of it and tries to hide it, B. He is proud of it and uses it as an excuse, C. He acknowledges it but refuses to let it hold him back, D. He is indifferent to it and doesn't think it matters Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the story of Jim Abbott used to illustrate? Options: A. The importance of having two arms to play baseball, B. The challenges of playing sports with a disability, C. The power of practice and determination in overcoming obstacles, D. The limitations of people with disabilities Correct Option: None
Question 6: How do people often react to the speaker's appearance? Options: A. They are inspired by his confidence and abilities, B. They are indifferent to his disability, C. They judge him and underestimate his abilities, D. They pity him and try to help him Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the speaker's message to people who may be facing obstacles? Options: A. Give up and accept your limitations, B. Use your obstacles as an excuse for not trying, C. Prove others wrong and work hard to overcome your obstacles, D. Ignore your obstacles and pretend they don't exist Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the speaker's goal in sharing his story? Options: A. To gain sympathy and attention, B. To inspire others to overcome their obstacles, C. To show off his athletic abilities, D. To complain about the challenges he faces Correct Option: None
Question 9: How does the speaker feel about people's pity or sympathy? Options: A. He appreciates it and seeks it out, B. He is indifferent to it, C. He rejects it and doesn't want to be pitied, D. He uses it to his advantage Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the overall tone of the speaker's talk? Options: A. Negative and pessimistic, B. Positive and inspiring, C. Neutral and informative, D. Angry and confrontational Correct Option: None

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As you can see, I was born without fingers on my right hand. And also my right leg was several inches shorter than my left one. They broke the bones in the leg, then they screwed metal spikes into the bone. It has not only spikes, but wires that go all the way through the leg to stabilize it. I have to walk on it. I have to stretch it out so that my muscles don't just get all atrophied. People always ask me, "Does it hurt?" Yes, it does, but I focus on what I can do, not on what I cannot do. I want to talk with you guys about overcoming obstacles. Everybody has obstacles, a disability, a hurdle. We face a choice: Let the obstacle overcome you or overcome the obstacle. Maybe some of you have heard of Jim Abbott. He was a Major League baseball player. He won a gold metal in the Olympics. He played for the Yankees, the Angels. But he threw a no-hitter, and he only had one arm. When he was a kid, he came home mad one time and told his dad, "The kids won't let me play baseball because I only have one hand." His dad replied, "No, the kids won't let you play baseball because you stink at baseball. You can't change the fact that you only have one hand, but you can change the fact that you stink." So, his dad began to practice with him, and he got good. He overcame obstacles. Teams would try to exploit his weak side. They would try to bunt to the side that he had a missing arm. But they never succeeded because he practiced and practiced fielding bunts to that side. There's no dishonor in having a disability, and I won't let anyone diss my ability, but I don't want anyone's pity either. I will not use the obstacles I face as an excuse for having a pity party. I will practice harder, play harder, and push myself harder to keep getting better. Last season I started on my varsity high school basketball team as a freshman, and I won Rookie of the Year. I was one of the top scorers on the team. One of the things that I find funny is that people judge me by appearance. They say, "Oh, look at this one-handed whitey with the limp. I don't want him on my team!" But what they don't know is that I don't just have a disability, I have an ability. One of my favorite moments from this last season was we played a team that we had never played before. And when the game started, you could tell that they were dissing my disability. I mean, they double-teamed our tallest player. They just were playing really soft on me, and they just, you could tell they thought, "What can this guy with one hand do?" So, they left me open for a three. I made that one. They left me open for another one. I made that one. Then, they started to get frustrated, so they actually fouled me. I made both free throws. And they called time out. And as we were in the huddle, I could hear the other coach yelling at his players about me. They went from not covering me at all to double-teaming me. It's all about overcoming obstacles. It's true, I have a disability, but so do you. I also have an ability, so do you. Everyone has obstacles to overcome. Some are visible like mine. Some are less visible. Maybe your obstacle is that you come from a poor neighborhood. Maybe people say you'll never amount to anything. Prove them wrong. Maybe your obstacle is that you have a learning disability, and people think that you're dumb. Prove them wrong. Maybe people judge you because of the color of your skin or your family background. Prove them wrong. I know a lot of people who take one look at me and judge me. They say, "Oh, that kid can't be any good at basketball. One leg, one hand." If someone things you can't overcome the obstacles, prove them wrong.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following are true of Steven?
Options: A. Steven was born with no fingers on his right hand, B. Steven’s legs were different lengths, C. A and B, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C
